what_it_is.title: What is Limited Company Formation?
what_it_is.content: Limited company formation creates a separate legal entity for your business, offering liability protection and potential tax advantages. It's suitable for businesses with higher profits or those seeking professional credibility.
industry_notes: Contractors and freelancers often incorporate to reduce tax liability and manage IR35 compliance
E-commerce businesses benefit from limited liability when selling to consumers
Professional services use limited companies for credibility and client confidence

faq.q: What are the benefits of forming a limited company in Kent?
faq.a: Limited companies offer liability protection, potential tax advantages (Corporation Tax vs Income Tax), professional credibility, and easier access to business funding. For profitable businesses, the tax savings often exceed the additional compliance costs.

faq.q: How long does company formation take in the UK?
faq.a: Electronic incorporation through Companies House typically takes 24-48 hours. We can expedite this to same-day incorporation for urgent requirements. Postal applications take 8-10 days.

faq.q: Do I need a registered office address in Kent?
faq.a: Yes, every company needs a UK registered office address. This can be your home address, but many businesses prefer to use a professional address. We provide registered office services for privacy and professionalism.

faq.q: What ongoing obligations do limited companies have?
faq.a: Companies must file annual accounts, confirmation statements, and Corporation Tax returns with HMRC. They also need proper bookkeeping, board meetings, and dividend documentation. We handle all these requirements.

faq.q: Should I incorporate as a sole trader or limited company?
faq.a: The decision depends on your profits, liability concerns, and tax situation. Generally, limited companies become tax-efficient when profits exceed £12,570 annually, but each situation is unique.

faq.q: Can I change from sole trader to limited company later?
faq.a: Yes, you can incorporate an existing sole trader business. This involves transferring assets, closing sole trader records with HMRC, and setting up company systems. We manage the entire transition process.
